description.narrative:
Projektet, som genomförs av UNDP sedan 2013, svarade upp mot rekommendationerna från Global Commission on HIV and the Law (GC) som hölls 2012. Rekommendationerna från GC betonade att stigma, diskriminering och kränkningar av mänskliga rättigheter fortsatt utgör stora hinder för att effektivt motarbeta HIV över hela världen, inklusive Afrika söder om Sahara. De rekommendationer som kom från GC formade insatsens fokus på fyra områden inom de rättsliga aspekterna av HIV; straffrätt, kvinnor, tillgång till behandling samt barn och ungdomar. Denna insats är en fortsättning på ett tidigare treårigt projekt och kommer fortsätta att bistå länder att följa upp rekommendationerna. UNDP kommer i den nya projektfasen, fas II att arbeta med utvecklingsmålet att stärka sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter i Afrika söder om Sahara. Inom denna insats är UNDPs övergripande mål att stärka de legala ramverken kring hiv och SRHR, samt att stödja åtnjutandet av mänskliga rättigheter för hbtq-personer samt kvinnor och flickor i Afrika söder om Sahara.
Fyra specifika projektmål har identifierats: 1) Att stärka förståelsen av lämpliga indikatorer samt uppföljning och utvärdering som bidrar till att främja ansvarsutkrävande vid genomförande av aktiviteter som bidrar till åtnjutandet av mänskliga rättigheter som kommer fram vid så kallade Legal Environment Assessment (LEA), dvs. systematiska analyser av befintlig lagstiftning och brister i denna ur ett rättighetsperspektiv på landnivå. 2) Att stärka kapaciteten hos nationella regeringarna att införa rättssystem som respekterar hbt-personers, kvinnors och flickors rättigheter. 3) Att stärka kapaciteten hos regionala och nationella civilsamhällesorganisationer i att göra anspråk på rättigheter och förespråka stärkta nationella rättsmiljöer, samt 4) Att stärka kapaciteten och ledarskapet inom de regionala ekonomiska gemenskaperna (RECs) för att underlätta för medlemsstaterna att införa juridiska reformer som respekterar hbt-personers, kvinnors och flickors rättigheter.
Fas II är en uppföljning av resultaten från fas I och kommer att genomföras i följande 12 länder: Angola, Burkina Faso, Kamerun, Tchad, Demokratiska republiken Kongo, Gabon, Ghana, Namibia, Lesotho, Moçambique, Sydafrika och Swaziland. För att uppnå målen inom fas II kommer följande huvudsakliga aktiviteter att genomföras; -Bedömningar av den lokala lagstiftningen ur ett rättighetsperspektiv för att sedan kunna genomföra reformer inom lagstiftningen, -Juridisk översyn av gällande lagar, -Genomföra nationella dialoger med företrädare för lagstiftande myndigheter och representanter för det civila samhället( CSOs) och med stöd från regionala ekonomiska gemenskaper (RECs) - Baserat på dialogerna, ta fram nationella årgärdsplaner för reformer inom hiv och lagar. - Insatsen kommer också att genomföra aktiviteter kring information och upplysning i rättsliga frågor för parlamentariker och allmänhet samt, - Främja tillgång till rättslig prövning genom brottsbekämpning, erbjuda juridiska tjänster och program för medvetandegörande i människorättsfrågor.
Den totala kostnaden för projektet är 45 MSEK varav Sida kommer att finansiera 35 MSEK (80%) av den planerade budget under en period på 3 år. UNDP kommer att finansiera resterande 10 MSEK (20%) av den totala budgeten.

UNDP work with the development objective to strengthen Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights in Sub-Saharan Africa and through this intervention, its overall intention will be to strengthen national and regional legal environments relating to HIV & SRHR to support the enjoyment of human rights of LGBT people, women and girls in Sub-Saharan Africa.
The intervention has four specific objectives; 1) Strengthening the understanding of appropriate indicators and monitoring and evaluation processes that help promote accountability for implementation of human rights enabling activities that arise from legal assessments, 2) Strengthening the capacity of national governments to put in place legal environments that respect the rights of LGBT people and women and girls, 3) Strengthening the capacity of regional and national civil society organizations including community-based groups to claim rights and advocate for strengthened national legal environments and 4) Strengthening the capacity and leadership of regional economic communities to facilitate Member States to put in place legal environments that respect the rights of LGBT people and women and girls.
Phase II is a follow up from the achievements of Phase I and will be implemented in 12 countries; Angola, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Chad, DRC, Gabon, Ghana, Namibia, Lesotho, Mozambique, South Africa and Swaziland. In order to achieve the objective of Phase II the following main activities will be carried out; - Legal environment assessments will be carried out to inform legislative reform, - Legal Reviews of prevailing laws, - National dialogue which will incorporate input from Regional Economic Communities (REC’s) and Civil Society Organization (CSO’s) and support to national action planning processes on HIV & SRHR and the Law.
The intervention will also supports judicial and Parliamentarian sensitization in order to promote access to justice through law enforcement. Legal services and legal/human rights literacy programs as well as Knowledge management will also be implemented through this intervention.
The total cost of this intervention is 45 MSEK of which Sida is requested to fund 35 MSEK (80%) of its planned budget over a period of 3 years. UNDP will fund the remaining 10 MSEK (20%) the total Project budget.

The overall Programme Objective of Phase II will be to strengthen national and regional legal environments relating to HIV & SRHR , particularly relating to prevention of child marriages and sexual and gender based violence, including FGM and to human rights for LGBT people. The intervention will achieve its outcomes at two levels; the first will focus on law, policy or strategy review, implementation or enforcement of laws relating to HIV & SRHR which positively impact on women and girls. the second outcome level will look at law, policy and strategy review implementation or enforcement of laws relating to HIV & SRHR which positively impact on LGBT persons.

description.narrative: BackgroundKey populations in many countries in Sub-Saharan Africa face broad stigma and discrimination and there is a gap in focused advocacy for legal review, legal reform, and strategies to strengthen access to justice and law enforcement for those key populations. As part of its commitment on the recommendations from the Global Commission, UNDP Regional Service Centre Africa, with the assistance of the government of Sweden, launched a programme aimed at addressing this gap. The programme, “Strengthening Regional and National Legislative Environments for HIV/SRHR to Support the Enjoyment of Human Rights of LGBT People and Women and Girls in Sub-Saharan Africa – Phase II,” was implemented through UNDP Country Offices in ten countries (Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Chad, Democratic Republic of Congo, Gabon, Ghana, Lesotho, Namibia Sierra Leone and Swaziland) with financial and/or technical support from the UNDP HIV, Health and Development Team (HHD) in Istanbul. The original grant period was 1 January 2016 to 31 December 2018, which was extended to 30 June 2019 through a no-cost extension. The development objective of the programme is “to strengthen sexual and reproductive health and rights in Sub-Saharan Africa". The program objective was “to strengthen national and regional legal environments relating to HIV and sexual and reproductive health and rights to support the enjoyment of human rights of LGBT people and women and girls in Sub-Saharan Africa". To achieve the program objective, the programme had the following four specific objectives:1. Strengthening the capacity of national governments to put in place legal environments that respect the rights of LGBT people and women and girls;2. Strengthening the capacity of regional and national civil society organizations including community-based groups to claim rights and advocate for strengthened national legal environments;3. Strengthening the capacity and leadership of regional economic communities to facilitate Member States to put in place legal environments that respect the rights of LGBT people and women and girls; and4. Strengthening the understanding of appropriate indicators and monitoring and evaluation processes that help promote accountability for implementation of human rights enabling activities that arise from legal assessments. The stakeholders for the programme included governments reviewing legal environments, relevant ministries and commissions, civil society organisations and community-based organisations including networks of people living with HIV and AIDS, other LGBT people and women and girls, legal experts, members of the judiciary, regional economic communities and the African Union Commission. Achievements In most countries, the Legal Environment Assessments for HIV (LEA) developed by UNDP has been a core component of this programme. The entire LEA process might be considered an important capacity-building process which provides a step-by-step guidance with concrete case studies, tools and resources to assist governments, civil society and other key stakeholders to develop evidence-informed decisions for effective HIV responses. The LEA was usually followed by a multi-stakeholder validation and/or planning meeting, which led to the implementation of follow-on activities including advocacy and capacity building, often with a view to informing changes in laws, policies, strategies or practices. An engagement scan may be carried out somewhere in this process to help identify strategic opportunities fortrying to effect change. By June 2019, the majority of activities planned were completed, with all countries reporting on achievements and results. Below are some examples of law and policy reforms and changes related to HIV/SRHR, LGBT, women and girls in countries where LEA´s and action plans were completed; Parliament in Malawi voted to decriminalize HIV transmission in the Malawi HIV Bill. A coalition of women’s groups led advocacy campaigns to remove Section 43 of the Draft Bill. UNDP supported the process since 2012 and one of the contributing factors was the LEA conducted with UNDP support in 2012-13 that recommended removing this provision. In Nambia, action planning was completed and recommendations for follow up included law review to eradicate HIV-related discrimination; clarity and uniformity on the age of consent for young people’s access to SRHR; decriminalization of adult consensual same-sex; eradication of forced sterilization of women living with HIV; and recommendations to stop unjust use of non-criminal laws to harass people engaged in transactional sex. In Lesotho, the Technical Working Group met to draft an Action Plan, prioritizing law review to end child marriage; promote equality in inheritance; review the criminalization of non-disclosure of HIV status and to protect the equality and health rights of key populations. Lesotho also ensured the enactment of Domestic Violence Bill by 2019 and plans to review and adopt a law to end child marriage. Based on the recommendations of the LEA, the Government of Burkina Faso: is aiming to repeal criminalization of HIV transmission. During 17th NAC session held on 25 October 2018, the Burkina Faso Head of State, who is the Chair of the National AIDS Council, formally agreed that there was a need to review and amend the legal framework of the national response to HIV, and to repeal any provision that would be counter-productive and not aligned to international and regional instruments that Burkina Faso is signatory to. DR Congo amended its old HIV law and repealed Article 45 that criminalized HIV transmission. Additionally, the amendments provide for sexually active adolescents to test and get test results without parental consent – which was a sticking point during the deliberations. In eSwatini, with support given for legislative reform by UNDP, the Sexual Offences and Domestic Violence bill was approved into an Act (SODVA 2018). Additionally, UNDP supported the Government to finalize the National Guidelines for the Multi-Sectoral Response to Sexual and Gender-Based Violence in Eswatini. In Gabon, UNDP and UNAIDS jointly provided guidance for drafting a national policy on gender and sexual violence based on LEA recommendations.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
